issue.title: Remove need to have an extra line in email csv file
issue.body:
**Background**

As a developer, I want to be able to send emails without an extra line at the top of the email CSV file so that I can send emails without and extra step

**Description**

The CSV for emails requires an extraneous line at the top of the CSV file as seen here: https://github.com/cal-itp/reports/blob/main/reports/test_emails.csv#L1 due to https://github.com/cal-itp/reports/blob/main/reports/generate_report_emails.py#L43

This can be removed so that it is easier to create a test or full set of emails.

**Acceptance criteria**

- [ ] Run test emails without extra line at head

issue.title: User Story: Information Organized by Vendor
issue.body:
### Summary


As a transit agency, Cal-ITP team member, or other interested party, I want to see information and metrics organized by vendor on reports.calitp.org so that I can make informed decisions on vendor selection and see the level of service received by others with my current vendor in order to effectively manage relationships and deliver the best data possible to transit riders.


### Acceptance Criteria


1. When viewing pages such as [this monthly index](https://reports.calitp.org/gtfs_schedule/2022/07/), it is possible to group/filter the report links by vendor(s) used (drop-down bar with vendor info)
1. When viewing [individual reports](https://reports.calitp.org/gtfs_schedule/2022/07/300/index.html), vendor names and associated information are prominently displayed, including multiple vendors as appropriate (for example, agency uses a different vendor for GTFS static vs. RT)
~~2. A separately formatted report is available for each vendor, summarizing the number of agencies using that vendor as well as data quality and performance metrics as appropriate.~~

### Notes

Data is tracked in Transit Technology Stacks Airtable base.

This has been a very common request from agencies and Cal-ITP/Caltrans staff.

### Tester [Stakeholder]

1. @edasmalchi 
2. @o-ram (optional)

# Sprint Ready Checklist
1. - [ ] Acceptance criteria defined
3. - [ ] Team understands acceptance criteria
4. - [ ] Team has defined solution / steps to satisfy acceptance criteria
5. - [ ] Acceptance criteria is verifiable / testable
6. - [ ] External / 3rd Party dependencies identified

comment.body: Part of this ticket is the prep needed to look into the warehouse data to make sure that all of the agencies have a vendor associated with them.

issue.title: Make the Charts Accessible
issue.body:
**Background**

As a user, I want an accessible version of the charts produced in every report page so that I can understand the chart data using a screen reader or other accessibility tool.

**Acceptance criteria**

- [ ] All charts are published in a format that can be consumed by a screen reader
- [ ] A public standard like WCAG can be applied, if it is identified

comment.body:
First step is choosing a charting library that doesn't just print out images. SVGs are ideal because the data can be exposed accessibly within the markup as opposed to canvas or images.

I've done some research on this. High Charts has the [most accessible](https://www.highcharts.com/docs/accessibility/accessibility-module) [options](https://www.highcharts.com/blog/accessibility/) I could find. However it is $150 a year license which I don't know if we can procure. Will find out.

I've reviewed the current D3-based, fully open-source charting libraries. Most of them are not actively maintained. I'm investigating [BillboardJS](https://github.com/naver/billboard.js) as option for a library that we can use that I can enhance.

I'm using a couple of D3-based guides https://www.a11ywithlindsey.com/blog/accessibility-d3-bar-charts, https://css-tricks.com/accessible-svgs, https://handbook.digital.ca.gov/tech/fast-dashboards; and will evaluate creating a solution that is just custom D3. I'd like to use a library as it will make it quicker in the future to add more types of graphs with less dev overhead.

Another consideration is that the current charts don't have a legend on them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/512243/187493828-8fd10dcb-6b26-464a-b2bd-1a3b01c0fa21.png)

Adding a legend might be a design consideration and take more resources on our end. Will discuss on that end as well.

issue.title: User Story: Information Organized by Vendor
issue.body:
### Summary


As a transit agency, Cal-ITP team member, or other interested party, I want to see information and metrics organized by vendor on reports.calitp.org so that I can make informed decisions on vendor selection and see the level of service received by others with my current vendor in order to effectively manage relationships and deliver the best data possible to transit riders.


### Acceptance Criteria


1. When viewing pages such as [this monthly index](https://reports.calitp.org/gtfs_schedule/2022/07/), it is possible to group/filter the report links by vendor(s) used (drop-down bar with vendor info)
1. When viewing [individual reports](https://reports.calitp.org/gtfs_schedule/2022/07/300/index.html), vendor names and associated information are prominently displayed, including multiple vendors as appropriate (for example, agency uses a different vendor for GTFS static vs. RT)
~~2. A separately formatted report is available for each vendor, summarizing the number of agencies using that vendor as well as data quality and performance metrics as appropriate.~~

### Notes

Data is tracked in Transit Technology Stacks Airtable base.

This has been a very common request from agencies and Cal-ITP/Caltrans staff.

### Tester [Stakeholder]

1. @edasmalchi 
2. @o-ram (optional)

# Sprint Ready Checklist
1. - [ ] Acceptance criteria defined
3. - [ ] Team understands acceptance criteria
4. - [ ] Team has defined solution / steps to satisfy acceptance criteria
5. - [ ] Acceptance criteria is verifiable / testable
6. - [ ] External / 3rd Party dependencies identified

comment.body: Part of this ticket is the prep needed to look into the warehouse data to make sure that all of the agencies have a vendor associated with them.

issue.title: Make the Charts Accessible
issue.body:
**Background**

As a user, I want an accessible version of the charts produced in every report page so that I can understand the chart data using a screen reader or other accessibility tool.

**Acceptance criteria**

- [ ] All charts are published in a format that can be consumed by a screen reader
- [ ] A public standard like WCAG can be applied, if it is identified

comment.body:
First step is choosing a charting library that doesn't just print out images. SVGs are ideal because the data can be exposed accessibly within the markup as opposed to canvas or images.

I've done some research on this. High Charts has the [most accessible](https://www.highcharts.com/docs/accessibility/accessibility-module) [options](https://www.highcharts.com/blog/accessibility/) I could find. However it is $150 a year license which I don't know if we can procure. Will find out.

I've reviewed the current D3-based, fully open-source charting libraries. Most of them are not actively maintained. I'm investigating [BillboardJS](https://github.com/naver/billboard.js) as option for a library that we can use that I can enhance.

I'm using a couple of D3-based guides https://www.a11ywithlindsey.com/blog/accessibility-d3-bar-charts, https://css-tricks.com/accessible-svgs, https://handbook.digital.ca.gov/tech/fast-dashboards; and will evaluate creating a solution that is just custom D3. I'd like to use a library as it will make it quicker in the future to add more types of graphs with less dev overhead.

Another consideration is that the current charts don't have a legend on them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/512243/187493828-8fd10dcb-6b26-464a-b2bd-1a3b01c0fa21.png)

Adding a legend might be a design consideration and take more resources on our end. Will discuss on that end as well.

issue.title: Make the Charts Accessible
issue.body:
**Background**

As a user, I want an accessible version of the charts produced in every report page so that I can understand the chart data using a screen reader or other accessibility tool.

**Acceptance criteria**

- [ ] All charts are published in a format that can be consumed by a screen reader
- [ ] A public standard like WCAG can be applied, if it is identified

comment.body: @ryon This looks good! I think we can move forward with tabbed example for now. Some feedback for when it is actually put on the site is to match the font of the existing site and to make sure the labels are as larger than the codepen example.

issue.title: Remove need to have an extra line in email csv file
issue.body:
**Background**

As a developer, I want to be able to send emails without an extra line at the top of the email CSV file so that I can send emails without and extra step

**Description**

The CSV for emails requires an extraneous line at the top of the CSV file as seen here: https://github.com/cal-itp/reports/blob/main/reports/test_emails.csv#L1 due to https://github.com/cal-itp/reports/blob/main/reports/generate_report_emails.py#L43

This can be removed so that it is easier to create a test or full set of emails.

**Acceptance criteria**

- [ ] Run test emails without extra line at head

issue.title: User Story: Information Organized by Vendor
issue.body:
### Summary


As a transit agency, Cal-ITP team member, or other interested party, I want to see information and metrics organized by vendor on reports.calitp.org so that I can make informed decisions on vendor selection and see the level of service received by others with my current vendor in order to effectively manage relationships and deliver the best data possible to transit riders.


### Acceptance Criteria


1. When viewing pages such as [this monthly index](https://reports.calitp.org/gtfs_schedule/2022/07/), it is possible to group/filter the report links by vendor(s) used (drop-down bar with vendor info)
1. When viewing [individual reports](https://reports.calitp.org/gtfs_schedule/2022/07/300/index.html), vendor names and associated information are prominently displayed, including multiple vendors as appropriate (for example, agency uses a different vendor for GTFS static vs. RT)
~~2. A separately formatted report is available for each vendor, summarizing the number of agencies using that vendor as well as data quality and performance metrics as appropriate.~~

### Notes

Data is tracked in Transit Technology Stacks Airtable base.

This has been a very common request from agencies and Cal-ITP/Caltrans staff.

### Tester [Stakeholder]

1. @edasmalchi 
2. @o-ram (optional)

# Sprint Ready Checklist
1. - [ ] Acceptance criteria defined
3. - [ ] Team understands acceptance criteria
4. - [ ] Team has defined solution / steps to satisfy acceptance criteria
5. - [ ] Acceptance criteria is verifiable / testable
6. - [ ] External / 3rd Party dependencies identified

comment.body: Part of this ticket is the prep needed to look into the warehouse data to make sure that all of the agencies have a vendor associated with them.

issue.title: Make the Charts Accessible
issue.body:
**Background**

As a user, I want an accessible version of the charts produced in every report page so that I can understand the chart data using a screen reader or other accessibility tool.

**Acceptance criteria**

- [ ] All charts are published in a format that can be consumed by a screen reader
- [ ] A public standard like WCAG can be applied, if it is identified

comment.body:
First step is choosing a charting library that doesn't just print out images. SVGs are ideal because the data can be exposed accessibly within the markup as opposed to canvas or images.

I've done some research on this. High Charts has the [most accessible](https://www.highcharts.com/docs/accessibility/accessibility-module) [options](https://www.highcharts.com/blog/accessibility/) I could find. However it is $150 a year license which I don't know if we can procure. Will find out.

I've reviewed the current D3-based, fully open-source charting libraries. Most of them are not actively maintained. I'm investigating [BillboardJS](https://github.com/naver/billboard.js) as option for a library that we can use that I can enhance.

I'm using a couple of D3-based guides https://www.a11ywithlindsey.com/blog/accessibility-d3-bar-charts, https://css-tricks.com/accessible-svgs, https://handbook.digital.ca.gov/tech/fast-dashboards; and will evaluate creating a solution that is just custom D3. I'd like to use a library as it will make it quicker in the future to add more types of graphs with less dev overhead.

Another consideration is that the current charts don't have a legend on them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/512243/187493828-8fd10dcb-6b26-464a-b2bd-1a3b01c0fa21.png)

Adding a legend might be a design consideration and take more resources on our end. Will discuss on that end as well.

issue.title: Make the Charts Accessible
issue.body:
**Background**

As a user, I want an accessible version of the charts produced in every report page so that I can understand the chart data using a screen reader or other accessibility tool.

**Acceptance criteria**

- [ ] All charts are published in a format that can be consumed by a screen reader
- [ ] A public standard like WCAG can be applied, if it is identified and applied
